messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 22, 2016 - June 28, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-06-29T21:08:29Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-22T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-06-28T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160629-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-06-22T18:00Z-21:00Z. This slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-06-22. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated starting on 2016-06-25 due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above. However, the energetic electron fluxes remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-06-25T03:12Z     ~550            C               -95/25                45                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-06-28T12:24Z     ~677            C                99/10                17                          STEREO A                          
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-29T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-07-05T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions located on the solar disk that can produce solar flares or coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to increase due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2016-07-02. 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Juno, Spitzer),Space Weather Notification - CME (Juno, Spitzer)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-06-25T15:16:31Z
## Message ID: 20160625-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-06-25T03:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~550 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -95/25 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-06-25T03:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Juno and Spitzer.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Juno at 2016-07-04T01:40Z and Spitzer at 2016-06-28T06:30Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-06-25T03:12:00-CME-001):

(a) 2 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif

(b) 5.5 AU outer boundary
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_5.5_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_5.5_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_STA_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160625_093500_5.5_ENLIL_CONE_STB_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 15, 2016 - June 21, 2016,Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 15, 2016 - June 21, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-06-22T20:46:42Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-15T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-06-21T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160622-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-06-15T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-06-14.  The highest solar wind speed reached values higher than 750 km/s on 2016-06-15.  

A CME arrival was detected at the STEREO A spacecraft on 2016-06-20T13:00Z due to a S-type CME that started on 2016-06-16T07:48Z.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week. 

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed

Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-06-16T02:36Z     ~516            C              -170/82                40                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-06-20T16:54Z     ~560            C              -147/37                42                          STEREO A                          
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-22T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-06-28T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions located on the solar disk that can produce solar flares or coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to increase due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2016-06-24.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 08, 2016 - June 14, 2016,Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 08, 2016 - June 14, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-06-15T19:26:49Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-08T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-06-14T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160615-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-06-14T18:00Z to 2016-06-14T21:00Z. This moderate geomagnetic storm was caused by the coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 at the end of 2016-06-14.  The solar wind speed reached values of 772 km/s on 2016-06-15.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu (1 pfu = 1 particle flux unit = 1/cm^2/sec/steradian)  for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-06-09T01:48Z     ~531            C              -165/35                41                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-06-14T13:25Z     ~540            C               -44/16                22                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-15T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-06-21T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions located on the solar disk that can produce solar flares or coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to remain elevated for several days due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream described above.    


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm,Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-06-14T21:53:04Z
## Message ID: 20160614-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-06-14T18:00Z to 2016-06-14T21:00Z. 

The storm is caused by enhanced solar wind speed, density, and magnetic field.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-06-14T18:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 01, 2016 - June 07, 2016,Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 01, 2016 - June 07, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-06-09T01:45:35Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-01T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-06-07T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160609-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.     

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-06-06T03:00Z to 2016-06-06T06:00Z.  This moderate geomagnetic storm was caused by the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around late 2016-06-04 (see notifications 20160606-AL-001 and 20160606-AL-002).  Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma crossed the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2016-06-05T13:59Z due to the compression caused by the high speed stream (see notifications 20160605-AL-001 and 20160605-AL-002).  The highest value of solar wind speed reached ~693 km/s around 2016-06-06. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-06-14T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions located on the far side of the Sun that can produce solar flares or coronal mass ejections.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to become elevated around 2016-06-11 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.    

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm,Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-06-06T12:10:11Z
## Message ID: 20160606-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Geomagnetic Kp index reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-06-06T03:00Z to 2016-06-06T06:00Z. 

The storm was caused by the high speed stream starting around 2016-06-05.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-06-06T03:00:00-GST-001.

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-06-06T03:00Z to 2016-06-06T06:00Z. 


NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-06-06T03:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing,Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-06-05T14:34:26Z
## Message ID: 20160605-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2016-06-05T13:59Z.

The activity is associated with the high speed stream starting at 2016-06-04T23:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2016-06-05T13:59:00-MPC-001.

## Notes

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 25, 2016 - May 31, 2016,Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 25, 2016 - May 31, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-06-01T17:10:17Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-05-25T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-05-31T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160601-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-05-28T06:00Z-09:00Z and 2016-05-30T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This minor increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-05-27.  The solar wind speed reached values of 600 km/s around 2016-05-30.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-05-29T09:24Z     ~510            C                70/25                19                          SOHO                              
2016-05-31T17:09Z     ~514            C               149/-19               30                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-06-01T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-06-07T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There is currently some activity (flares and coronal mass ejections) originating from the active regions located on the far side and observed by the STEREO A EUVI.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to increase due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2016-06-04.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score
